text: when the world was still black and white
this man had Washington seeing red Fidel
Castro brought communism to the
Caribbean America's response an embargo
that's lasted 53 years now the White
House says it's ready to cut loose the
anchor of the past the revolution and
Castro's nationalization of US interests
threw down a gauntlet successive
American administrations responded with
threats and plots in 1961 the CIA
sponsored a disastrous attempt at
counter-revolution it ended in
humiliation at the Bay of Pigs
Cuba's reputation as a Cold War
flashpoint cemented the following year
in a missile crisis that brought the
world to the brink of nuclear war it
shall be the policy of this nation to
regard any nuclear missile launched from
Cuba against any nation in the Western
Hemisphere as an attack by the Soviet
Union on the United States requiring a
full retaliatory response upon the
Soviet Union the battle lines drawn up
amid such drama simply froze with time
Cuba's economy once so dependent on its
huge neighbor to the north withered
firmly in the Soviet camp Cuban troops
and advisors could be found in distant
Cold War conflicts in Angola and
Mozambique and all the while Fidel kept
up his fiery often long-winded rhetoric
the Cubans paid a heavy price in
economic hardship and political
repression many fled some prepared to
risk their lives making the 90 mile sea
crossing to Florida in Miami a brooding
resentful exiled population grew
wielding enormous influence on US policy
but as the old-timers have passed on
younger generations have started to talk
about dialogue
Fidel was getting old passing the reins
of power to his younger brother Raul and
slowly on both sides of this bitter
divide a tentative four began this
handshake at a memorial for Nelson
Mandela a year ago was a clear sign now
Washington says it no longer serves
America's interests to seek Cuba's
collapse it's time it says for a better
future Paul Adams BBC news
